Key Match Events: Mitchell Marsh hit 177* from 132 balls, hitting 26 boundaries during his knock.
David Warner followed to his own 50 off 52 balls, kicking on after getting his eye in against the spinners.
Warner was dismissed for 53 from 61 balls, caught by Najmul Hossain Shanto off Mustafizur Rahman.
Mitchell Marsh clubbed nine sixes in his 177*.
Steve Smith finished not out on 63* from 64 balls, as Australia reached the winning post with 32 balls to spare.
Marnus Labuschagne had a direct hand in four of Australia's dismissals, including the run outs of Najmul Hossain Shanto and Mahmudullah Riyad.
Najmul Hossain Shanto was run out despite a last-gasp dive.
Mahmudullah Riyad was caught out of his crease soon after attempting a quick single as Labuschagne swooped on the ball and threw down the stumps in one action that included a dive.
Sean Abbott dismissed Hasan for 36 from 34 balls, and then caught Das for 36.
Adam Zampa claimed Mushfiqur Rahim for 21.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Bangladesh's top five batters each made at least 30 but only Tawhid Hridoy (74) could turn a start into a fifty.
Bangladesh were able to amass 306/8 against Australia.
Australia lost Travis Head early in the chase when he played on while trying to take on Taskin Ahmed, as the ball took an inside edge and then kissed his stumps before rolling back to the keeper.
Bangladesh stand-in skipper Najmul Hossain Shanto and in-form veteran Mahmudullah Riyad formed a pair of ominous stands.
Bangladesh opening pair settled quickly and reached 62/0 at the end of 10 overs, while Australia failed to take a wicket in the first Powerplay for the fourth time in nine matches.
Others: Glenn Maxwell was handed a well-earned rest to get himself back into peak condition for the knockout stages.
Sean Abbott took a wicket in his Cricket World Cup debut.
Adam Zampa claimed outright first place for the most wickets at the tournament thus far.
Marnus Labuschagne had the most wickets at the Cricket World Cup thus far.
